title: For Fellowkids Studio Kiln Shows How Brands Can Behave Like Fans
source_credit: Work by For Fellowkids via The Brand Identity
summary: Studio Kiln engineered a vibrant brand identity for Fellowkids, a creative agency expanding across esports and entertainment. The strategic rebrand ingeniously positions the agency as a true fan, mirroring their expertise in cultivating community. Central to this is the versatile 'Fellowkid' character—an adaptable, collectible figure embodying shifting allegiances. Complemented by a Y2K-infused visual system and bespoke typography, this dynamic design ensures an authentic, engaging presence that resonates deeply with contemporary culture and reflects Fellowkids' ambitious growth.
fullContent:
Forging Fandom: Studio Kiln Reimagines Fellowkids' Identity

Fellowkids, an agency dedicated to cultivating vibrant fan communities, found its existing identity no longer reflected its dynamic ethos or the sophisticated scale of its growing clientele. The challenge was multifaceted: to craft a brand that captured their inherent "rock and roll" energy, transcended corporate posturing, and authentically mirrored the very fandom they championed. In a culture quick to spot inauthenticity, any solution had to embody genuine fan spirit, not merely imitate it, while matching the calibre of their expanding work and client base.

Studio Kiln's response was rooted in a deceptively profound insight: for an entity that builds fandom, its own brand must *behave* like a fan. This philosophy steered clear of corporate mimicry, instead aiming for an identity responsive, playful, and organically integrated with community dynamics. The embodiment of this vision emerged as the "Fellowkid" – a hooded figure, the identity’s emotional core and a universal silhouette instantly recognizable across diverse fan cultures. This shapeshifting icon, conceived initially as a physical vinyl art toy, represented a tangible commitment to collectibility, transforming the brand itself into a piece of fan culture and making the promise of fandom a palpable reality.

Around this iconic character, Studio Kiln constructed a vibrant Y2K-inspired visual ecosystem. This world pulsed with nostalgic tech cues, featuring a spectrum of translucent plastics, candy brights, saturated neons, and deep blacks, offering a versatile palette to amplify hype or ground the narrative with sophisticated hardware greys. Typographically, Aeonik served as the foundational anchor, its clear, neutral lines providing critical balance against the system's more bespoke, retro-flavoured display type. Aeonik Mono added a subtle technical inflection, ensuring contemporary usability while allowing the character and graphics to carry the emotional weight. A modular system, akin to a digital sticker sheet, completed the toolkit – a rich yet flexible framework of character icons, custom type, and decals, designed for agile, 'plug-and-play' application.

The impact of this rebrand was immediate and resonated deeply. Clients lauded the new identity's "fun, bright, clean, and exciting" energy, influencing pitch successes. The Fellowkid vinyl toy, especially, became a beloved symbol – a playful yet premium collectible that perfectly encapsulated Fellowkids' ethos: taking fandom seriously without taking themselves too seriously. Beyond commercial triumphs, the rebrand unlocked the agency's authentic "rock and roll" spirit, providing an identity that truly matched the calibre of their work and values. More than a visual refresh, it activated their true potential, inviting audiences to not just observe but to *root for* the Fellowkids brand, rekindling the deeply human impulse to collect, customize, and care.

title: How Kimera Built Cursors Identity Around A Custom Typeface System
source_credit: Work by How Kimera via The Brand Identity
summary: For the AI code editor Cursor, we meticulously developed a discerning brand refresh, positioning it as an indispensable tool for professional developers. Central to the strategy was a bespoke typeface system, Cursor Gothic, precisely engineered for both brand communication and product UI. This versatile font integrates unique logo ligatures and an optimized icon set, harmonizing technical sophistication with a refined user experience, ensuring visual cohesion across all touchpoints.
fullContent:
In the dynamic realm of type foundries, Cursor faced a distinctive brand challenge: to cultivate a cohesive visual identity through refinement, not reinvention. The core directive was to preserve the essence of Ben Barry’s original logo while enhancing its versatility and optimizing it for contemporary digital screens. This wasn't merely a technical brief; it demanded a nuanced balance, marrying high-end technical sophistication with an underlying current of soft, human warmth. Cursor’s existing appreciation for Kimera’s retail typeface, Waldenburg, provided a crucial starting point, signalling a desire not to alter its fundamental letterforms but to elevate its functional prowess and environmental integration.

The solution emerged as Cursor Gothic, a bespoke typeface meticulously crafted by Kimera, building upon Waldenburg’s structural integrity. This adaptation saw subtle yet impactful adjustments: a slightly more condensed form, more pronounced squarish shapes, and heightened contrast for smoother rhythm across diverse text sizes. A groundbreaking innovation lay in the development of "logo ligatures"—integrating Cursor's various logos and lockups directly into the font with optical precision, effectively collapsing the boundary between branding and typography by guaranteeing flawless alignment. Complementing this, a custom icon set was designed, its rounded caps and subtly squarish forms echoing the typeface's character, ensuring seamless functionality across the brand's website UI and its pivotal code editor interface.

The brand’s visual lexicon extended further with a refined logo system, evolving Ben Barry’s original cube design into three distinct versions. Crucially, geometric purity was often set aside for optical truth; subtle corner-rounding and cursor offsetting ensured legibility and impact across varying screen contexts. Defying typical tech industry aesthetics, the colour palette embraces a distinctive warm undertone, with an accent orange derived from the tangible world of power tools, injecting an authentic human touch. This holistic design ethos culminated in a website experience that transcends static presentation, integrating interactive product elements built directly in CSS, allowing users to engage with a live, functional representation of the desktop app, thus positioning Cursor as an industry leader through unparalleled digital immersion.

Ultimately, this comprehensive brand refresh for Cursor isn't about transformation, but amplification. It’s a strategic foundation reset, leveraging existing equity and distilling core ingredients to be fewer, yet profoundly better. The forthcoming Cursor Mono, a monospace extension, will close the circle, establishing a singular typographic language that seamlessly bridges brand communication with the actual product environment where developers work. This project stands as a testament to the power of a unified design strategy, demonstrating how meticulous attention to type, iconography, and interactive experience can create a consistent, deeply integrated identity that resonates across every touchpoint.

title: How Wedge Shifted Allergen Brand Growhappy From Fear To Confidence
source_credit: Work by How Wedge via The Brand Identity
summary: For GrowHappy, we engineered a strategic rebrand to transform the infant allergen introduction landscape. We pioneered 'ImmunoNutrition' to reframe early exposure as immune system development, moving beyond fear-based narratives. Our visual identity draws from comforting storybooks, utilizing soft palettes and approachable typography to create a reassuring, empathetic experience. This integrated design system empowers parents, establishing GrowHappy as the confident leader in proactive pediatric wellness.
fullContent:
The landscape of early allergen introduction for infants has long been fraught with anxiety, dominated by fear-based messaging and a clinical aesthetic. GrowHappy, born from founder Stephanie Wibom's personal journey with her daughter's allergies and collaborating with leading pediatric experts, aimed to bridge the critical gap between scientific evidence and actionable, reassuring solutions. The challenge for independent creative studio Wedge was significant: to not merely present facts, but to strategically reposition the entire category, shifting parental mindset from apprehension to confidence. This demanded a complete visual and verbal departure, fostering empowerment where fear had previously reigned.

Wedge's strategic breakthrough arrived through the power of language. Recognizing the need to transcend the existing fear paradigm, the studio coined an entirely new category: ImmunoNutrition. This pivotal term reframes early allergen exposure as a deliberate act of nourishing and fortifying a child's developing immune system. Paired with a product line aptly named ImmunoButters, the concept immediately communicates both its format and profound benefits. This semantic innovation not only distinguishes GrowHappy as a clear category leader but also creates vital emotional distance from competitors, empowering parents with a newfound sense of food freedom and informed choice.

The visual identity for GrowHappy deliberately veers from conventional clinical aesthetics, finding inspiration in comforting storybooks and classic baby products. This psychological pivot offers reassurance, employing a soft, muted color palette that sharply contrasts with typical bold primaries or sterile whites. The type system skillfully balances clarity, authority, and warmth, conveying expertise without intimidation. A cornerstone of the visual language is the intricate illustration style, reminiscent of vintage botanical fruit-and-vegetable plates. This choice communicates whole food goodness, imbues the brand with heritage and trustworthiness, and provides a gentle, educational layer, making complex science approachable. Every detail, from these illustrations to the considered information architecture on the packaging, works in concert to make parents feel capable and supported.

The culmination of this thoughtful branding effort is a GrowHappy that stands as both an expert guide and an empathetic companion. The design meticulously avoids any clinical or fear-driven cues, instead presenting soft, organized, and reassuring touchpoints. Parents instantly grasp the product's purpose and significance, fostering confidence through clarity. This holistic approach communicates a transformative message: allergens are not threats to be cautiously managed, but integral components of a wholesome diet essential for robust immune health and gut development. Launched as the pioneer in the ImmunoNutrition category, GrowHappy, through its strategic linguistic invention and warm, sophisticated visual system, has successfully cultivated a new conversation – one where early allergen introduction is embraced as an act of nourishment, empowering families to approach their child’s nutrition with courage, not trepidation.

title: Los Yorks Pixel Based System Gives Netflixs Eyeline A Bold New Vision
source_credit: Work by Los Yorks via The Brand Identity
summary: Los York engineered a sophisticated brand identity for Eyeline, Netflix's premier VFX partner, evolving beyond its Scanline legacy. The core concept leverages the pixel as the foundational unit for limitless visual creation. A scalable, modular framework, differentiated by an RGB spectrum across its VFX, Studios, and Labs divisions, ensures adaptable coherence. Typography merges classic cinematic elegance with modern digital clarity, establishing a distinctive, forward-looking visual language that skillfully avoids industry clichés.
fullContent:
Eyeline, a powerhouse in visual effects, virtual production, and experimental technology, faced the intricate challenge of unifying its three distinct divisions – VFX, Studios, and Labs – under a singular, compelling identity. The goal was to forge a cohesive system that allowed each arm to maintain its unique voice, yet resonate as part of a greater, innovative whole. Beyond mere visual distinction, the project sought to transcend the often-clichéd, overtly technical aesthetics prevalent in the VFX industry. The brief called for an identity that could articulate Eyeline's profound thinking and creative ingenuity, rather than merely showcasing technology. Crucially, the solution needed to bridge bespoke craftsmanship with operational scale, particularly in their partnership with global giants like Netflix, all while honoring legacy and charting future innovation.

Los York's visionary response centered on a deceptively simple yet profoundly resonant idea: the pixel as the elemental origin of all vision. This fundamental building block became a powerful metaphor for Eyeline’s synergistic blend of technology and creativity, where a single point of light can blossom into expansive worlds. From this core concept emerged a sophisticated, grid-based design language, designed for infinite scalability and expression. This modular system elegantly mirrors Eyeline's collaborative workflow, adapting seamlessly from micro-details to macro-expressions across film sets, digital pipelines, and R&D environments – a balance of clarity, control, and dynamic movement. Each of Eyeline’s three divisions found its unique voice through a dynamic color palette: red for Studios, green for VFX, and blue for Labs – forming a complete RGB spectrum, a subtle yet potent nod to the foundational elements of digital image-making.

The typographic strategy reinforces this duality of imagination and engineering. It thoughtfully pairs the cinematic warmth and historical weight of ITC Garamond Light Narrow with the modern, technical precision of Netflix Sans. This deliberate contrast not only grounds the brand in filmmaking's rich legacy but also telegraphs its forward-thinking digital presence, acknowledging its vital partnership with the streaming giant. This refined blend creates a distinct typographic voice, harmonizing tradition with innovation. Critically, Los York consciously eschewed conventional VFX branding tropes, which often lean on overtly technical or flashy visuals. Instead, the identity positions the pixel as a clean, confident window and canvas, allowing Eyeline's exceptional craft and intellectual depth to take center stage. The resulting identity has been met with widespread acclaim from Eyeline's leadership and peers, successfully capturing the company's spirit and trajectory, solidifying its position as a creative force where technology truly meets possibility.
